1.Oscar Wilde: Be yourself. Everyone else is taken.

2.Victor Hugo: Even the darkest night will end and sun will rise.

3.Mary Shelley: Beware; for I am fearless, and therefore powerful.

4.Charlotte Brontë: I would always rather be happy than dignified.

5.Oscar Wilde: Always forgive your enemies; nothing annoys them so much.

6.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Skill to do comes of doing.

7.Margaret Fuller: Nature provides exceptions to every rule.

8.IDA B. WELLS-BARNETT: The way to right wrongs is to turn the light of truth upon them.

9.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Our greatest glory is not in never failing, but in rising up every time we fail.

10.Oscar Wilde: Man is least himself when he talks in his own person. Give him a mask, and he will tell the truth.

11.Walt Whitman: Simplicity is the glory of expression.

12.Margaret Fuller: Today a reader, tomorrow a leader.

13.Louisa May Alcott: I am not afraid of storms, for I am learning how to sail my ship.

14.Ralph Waldo Emerson: The purpose of life is not to be happy. It is to be useful, to be honorable, to be compassionate, to have it make some difference that you have lived and lived well.

15.Henry David Thoreau: Life isn’t about finding yourself; it’s about creating yourself. So live the life you imagined.

16.John Muir: Earth has no sorrow that earth cannot heal.

17.Oscar Wilde: I can resist everything except temptation.

18.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Live in the sunshine, swim the sea, drink the wild air.

19.Walt Whitman: Not I nor anyone else can travel that road for you. You must travel it by yourself. It is not far. It is within reach. Perhaps you have been on it since you were born, and did not know. Perhaps it is everywhere – on water and land.

20.Margaret Fuller: If you have knowledge, let others light their candles in it.

21.Ralph Waldo Emerson: A hero is no braver than an ordinary man, but he is brave five minutes longer.

22.Emily Dickinson: Hope is the thing with feathers That perches in the soul And sings the tune without the words And never stops at all.

23.Louisa May Alcott: Life is my college. May I graduate well, and earn some honors.

24.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Without ambition one starts nothing. Without work one finishes nothing. The prize will not be sent to you. You have to win it.

25.Herman Melville: It is better to fail in originality than to succeed in imitation.

26.Henry David Thoreau: The language of friendship is not words but meanings.

27.Walt Whitman: Give me the splendid, silent sun with all his beams full-dazzling.

28.Thomas Gray: Youth smiles without any reason. It is one of its chiefest charms.

29.Herman Melville: I know not all that may be coming, but be it what it will, I'll go to it laughing.

30.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Nothing great was ever achieved without enthusiasm.

32.Louisa May Alcott: He who believes is strong; he who doubts is weak. Strong convictions precede great actions.

33.Ralph Waldo Emerson: For every minute you remain angry, you give up sixty seconds of peace of mind.

34.Margaret Fuller: Nature provides exceptions to every rule.

35.Walt Whitman: The art of art, the glory of expression and the sunshine of the light of letters, is simplicity.

36.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Life is a journey, not a destination.

37.John Muir: Of all the paths you take in life, make sure a few of them are dirt.

38.Henry David Thoreau: What lies behind us and what lies ahead of us are tiny matters compared to what lives within us.

39.Margaret Fuller: Very early, I knew that the only object in life was to grow.

40.Herman Melville: A smile is the chosen vehicle of all ambiguities.

41.Louisa May Alcott: It's amazing how lovely common things become, if one only knows how to look at them.

42.Ralph Waldo Emerson: It is not the length of life, but the depth.

43.John Muir: Nature’s peace will flow into you as sunshine into trees.

44.Walt Whitman: I discover myself on the verge of a usual mistake.

45.Ralph Waldo Emerson: What lies behind you and what lies in front of you, pales in comparison to what lies inside of you.

46.Oscar Wilde: A man's face is his autobiography. A woman's face is her work of fiction.

48.Ralph Waldo Emerson: When it is dark enough, you can see the stars.

49.Henry David Thoreau: Most men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them.

50.Louisa May Alcott: The power of finding beauty in the humblest things makes home happy and life lovely.

51.Herman Melville: It is not down on any map; true places never are.

52.Walt Whitman: We don’t read and write poetry because it’s cute. We read and write poetry because we are members of the human race. And the human race is filled with passion. So medicine, law, business, engineering… these are noble pursuits and necessary to sustain life. But poetry, beauty, romance, love… these are what we stay alive for.

53.John Muir: Wilderness is a necessity… there must be places for human beings to satisfy their souls.

54.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Make the most of yourself….for that is all there is of you.

55.Emily Dickinson: That it will never come again is what makes life so sweet.

56.William Shakespeare: One touch of nature makes the whole world kin.

57.Ralph Waldo Emerson: He who is not everyday conquering some fear has not learned the secret of life.

58.Louisa May Alcott: I'd rather take coffee than compliments just now.

59.Margaret Fuller: Pain has no effect but to steal some of my time.

60.Ralph Waldo Emerson: I cannot remember the books I’ve read any more than the meals I have eaten; even so, they have made me.

61.Henry David Thoreau: Do not lose hold of your dreams or aspirations. For if you do, you may still exist but you have ceased to live.

62.Herman Melville: As for me, I am tormented with an everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts.

63.Walt Whitman: Battles are lost in the same spirit in which they are won.

64.Thomas Gray: Poetry is thoughts that breathe, and words that burn.

65.Louisa May Alcott: I've got the key to my castle in the air, but whether I can unlock the door remains to be seen.

66.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Be silly. Be honest. Be kind.

67.Oscar Wilde: True friends stab you in the front.

68.Margaret Fuller: Men for the sake of getting a living forget to live.

69.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Our chief want is someone who will inspire us to be what we know we could be.

70.Herman Melville: I try all things, I achieve what I can.

71.Henry David Thoreau: It matters not where or how far you travel — the farther commonly the worse — but how much alive you are.

72.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Once you make a decision, the universe conspires to make it happen.

74.John Muir: One day’s exposure to mountains is better than a cartload of books.

75.Ralph Waldo Emerson: There is a tendency for things to right themselves.

76.Walt Whitman: Do I contradict myself? Very well, then, I contradict myself; I am large – I contain multitudes.

77.Margaret Fuller: Give me truth; cheat me by no illusion.

78.Ralph Waldo Emerson: You cannot do a kindness too soon, for you never know how soon it will be too late.

79.Oscar Wilde: Always forgive your enemies; nothing annoys them so much.

80.Louisa May Alcott: A little kingdom I possess, where thoughts and feelings dwell; And very hard the task I find of governing it well.

81.Ralph Waldo Emerson: People that seem so glorious are all show; underneath, they are like everyone else.

84.Ralph Waldo Emerson: The only way to have a friend is to be one.

86.Walt Whitman: I am as bad as the worst, but, thank God, I am as good as the best.

89.Walt Whitman: All goes onward and outward, nothing collapses. And to die is different from what any one supposed, and luckier.

90.Ralph Waldo Emerson: The only person you are destined to become is the person you decide to be.

92.Herman Melville: A man thinks that by mouthing hard words he understands hard things.

95.Henry David Thoreau: Things do not change; we change.

96.Ralph Waldo Emerson: Don’t be too timid and squeamish about your actions. All life is an experiment. The more experiments you make the better.

104.Emily Dickinson: Saying nothing sometimes says the most.

113.Oscar Wilde: Art is the most intense mode of individualism that the world has known.

121.Louisa May Alcott: Good books, like good friends, are few and chosen; the more select, the more enjoyable.

years, I can cheerfully take it now, or with equal cheerfulness, I can wait.
